original: The Import Expander shall be able to do "smart expansion": for a given list of modules, it shall analyse the importing MicroPython procedure and only copy the subset of assignments of variables that are actually used in this procedure.[SEP]The rationale is to have a MicroPython module containi ng all symbols defined in a databaseas a set of MicroPython assignments  (this should be automated by a dedicated tool). For example, the following script could be produced from the engineering data repository:   # sdb.py   camera_1_id =  camera_2_id =  … MicroPython procedure can then import this file and use the required subset of variables. Since this imported module is arbitrarily large, it is sensible to requ ire that the Import Expander copies only t he required subset of assignments.  This solution assumes that there are no interdependencies between variables in the imported file . For example, the assignment    # sdb.py   …   camera_1_controller_id = camera_1_id * 100 +would fail if camera_1_id   is not referred in the importing module.his is why such mechanism is not required by default for all imported modules: only  the modules declared by the user are assumed to be simple assignments and can then be expanded without mistakes.[END]
modified: The Import Expander shall be able to do " smart expansion " : for a given list of modules , it shall analyse the importing <0> procedure and only copy the subset of assignments of variables that are actually used in this <1> rationale is to have a <2> module <3> ng all symbols defined in a <4> a set of <5> assignments <6> ( this should be automated by a dedicated tool ) . For example , the following script could be produced from the engineering data repository : <7> <8> <9> <10> <11> = <12> <13> = <14> … MicroPython procedure can then import this file and use the required subset of variables . Since this imported module is arbitrarily large , it is sensible to requ ire that the Import Expander copies only t he required subset of assignments . <15> This solution assumes that there are no interdependencies between variables in the imported file . For example , the assignment <16> # <17> <18> … <19> <20> = <21> * <22> <23> would fail if <24> <25> is not referred in the importing <26> is why such mechanism is not required by default for all imported modules : only <27> the modules declared by the user are assumed to be simple assignments and can then be expanded without <28> ]
augmented: The import expander should be able to perform "smart extensions": for a given list of modules, it should analyze the import < 0 > procedure and copy only the subset of variable assignments actually used in this < 1 > module. < 2 > module < 3 > ng all symbols defined in a < 4 > module < 5 > assignments < 6 > (this should be automated by a dedicated tool), for example, the following script could be generated from the Engineering Data Repository: < 7 > < 8 > < 9 > < 10 > < 11 > = < 12 > < 13 > =   < unk > MicroPyth

The Import Expander should be able to perform "smart extensions": For a given list of modules, it should analyze the import < 0 > procedure and copy only the subset of variable assignments actually used in this < 1 > module. < 2 > module < 3 > ng all symbols defined in a < 4 > module < 5 > assignments < 6 > (this should be automated by a dedicated tool), for example, the following script could be generated from the Engineering Data Repository: < 7 > < 8 > < 9 > < 10 > < 11 > = < 12 > < 13 > =   < unk > MicroPyth

original: The Initialization State shall be characterised by the following: -The state is entered by Remote Terminal Unit power-on or by a reset signal. -One redundancy of the Remote Terminal Unit Core is activated. -No commands via the Remote Terminal Unit Remote Control Interface are processed. -All configurable settings of the Remote Terminal Unit are initialized to the default values. -All memory areas related to programmable command or actuation sequences are cleared. -No actuation of any interfaces -The overall (redundancy) configuration of the Remote Terminal Unit is set according to the default values. -The Remote Terminal Unit (optionally) executes a self-test as defined in 7.2.2.[END]
modified: <0> <1> <2> shall be characterised by the following : -The state is entered by <3> <4> <5> power - on or by a reset signal . -One redundancy of <6> <7> <8> <9> <10> is activated . -No commands via <11> <12> <13> <14> <15> <16> <17> are processed . -All configurable settings of <18> <19> <20> <21> are initialized to the default values . -All memory areas related to programmable command or actuation sequences are cleared . -No actuation of any interfaces -The overall ( redundancy ) configuration of <22> <23> <24> <25> is set according to the default values . -The <26> <27> <28> ( optionally ) executes a self - test as defined in <29> ]
augmented: < 0 > < 1 > < 2 > is characterized as follows: -The state is enabled by < 3 > < 4 > < 5 > Power - one or by a reset signal. -A redundancy of < 6 > < 7 > < 8 > < 9 > < 10 > is enabled. -No commands above < 11 > < 12 > < 13 > < 14 > < 15 > < 16 > < 17 > are processed. -All configurable settings of < 18 > < 19 > < 20 > Unit are initialized to the default values. -All memory areas associated with programmable commands or operation sequences are deleted. -No bet
